results.title: Melbourne prepares for Olympic Games
results.brief_description: Originally produced for BBC Television, this film is a progress report on preparations for the XVIth Olympiad, 1956. At the Melbourne Cricket Ground, the main stadium for the Games, new triple-deck steel and concrete stands are under construction, the five acre arena has been completely regraded and foundations laid for running tracks. This stadium, the scene for the opening ceremony, the track and field events, the soccer and hockey finals will hold a record Olympic crowd of 110,000. At nearby Olympic Park, new arenas and racing tracks are under construction. Also in close proximity to the main stadium is the Olympic Swimming Pool, an unusual structure of ultramodern design in which roofing and sloping sides without conventional pillars, support seating for 5,000 spectators. At Heidelberg, Olympic Village is nearing completion, for the first time in the history of the Games, competing athletes of both sexes and from all countries will live together at the Village for the duration of the Games.

results.title: Melbourne Olympics
results.brief_description: After years of waiting, TV was finally broadcast in Australia – just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, which was aired by all three Melbourne TV stations and was the first Olympic Games outside of Europe and America.

constellations_primary.name: No guts, no glory
constellations_primary.description: TV arrived just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. The Olympics crystallise ideas of nationalism, athletic heroism, and controversy, all of which have been explored through countless features, documentaries and TV shows.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

results.description: After years of waiting, TV was finally broadcast in Australia – just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, which was aired by all three Melbourne TV stations and was the first Olympic Games outside of Europe and America.

results.title: Melbourne Cup 1896
results.brief_description: A clip of film that records the events that transpired on Melbourne Cup Day, 1896, including three seconds of the actual horse race. Maurice Sestier’s surviving footage of the 1896 Melbourne Cup is the earliest surviving cinema footage taken in Australia.

results.title: Melbourne : films of the fifties
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: A Comprehensive overview of a fascinating decade in the history of Melbourne and its environs, and a tribute to the many filmmakers who recorded the major - and minor - events which occurred in Melbourne in the 1950s. Told through clips from an astonishing range of newsreels, documentaries, travelogues, advertisements, home movies, dramatic features and short subjects - with a detailed commentary by Melbourne broadcaster Paul Higgins this vast array of footage has been arranged in six sections: Institutions (places, personalities, pasttimes) ; Growth (the baby boom, new government initiatives, urban sprawl) ; Events (sporting and cultural) ; The Games (the 1956 Olympics) ; Arrivals (fads and fashions, television and Tattersalls, celebrities and the consumer revolution) ; Change (or the lack of it!).

results.title: Melbourne's garden
results.brief_description: Colour studies of the Botanic Gardens; the many-coloured flowering shrubs, unending varieties of floral displays, shade of an oak lawn in summer, rockery plants providing brilliant colour, rose gardens with the newest varieties and the old favourites. The unusual foliage and blossoms to be found the Australian section; the delicate plant which flourish in the shelter of the glasshouses.

results.title: Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Unedited footage of Melbourne including people relaxing in a ‘garden’ in the city. Odd moment halfway through where an Aboriginal man (Jagajaga?) signs his name on an official-looking document

Contains an excellent ‘The End’ that features a watercolour image of Melbourne city overlooking the Yarra and towards St. Paul’s Cathederal.

results.title: Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Eric Thompson and Douglas White
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
This film, directed by Douglas White, opens to the roar of a crowd at the MCG. The camera then sweeps across the city of Melbourne as the soundtrack fades to an easy listening score by composer George Dreyfus (notable for his TV score works like the classic theme from Rush). The film has no commentary, just a skeleton narrative, which is ingeniously used to feature the city of Melbourne. We see a young man wave goodbye to his mum and drive past the commission flats to pick up his girlfriend (Meg from “Prisoner” - the young Elspeth Ballantyne). In the city, people work and shop and the music turns more dramatic as the crowds and traffic grow. In the evening the couple window shop for funky furniture and see “Busybody” at Her Majesty’s, then twist the light fantastic at a bar. Part of the Life in Australia series, produced by The Australian Commonwealth Film Unit.
